description.text: I accidentally discovered how to do this. It creates a sponge-like structure which may have several applications. Be careful when trying to remove part from bed.

Printer:

Anycubic Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I have a 0.4 mm nozzle and I set the printer to a 0.75 mm nozzle. Reduced extrusion multiplier to 0.45 (can be achieved by setting a bigger diameter filament) and feed of 2000 mm/min.

It takes some try and error to get the right build, you will want to play with extrusion multiplier, starting height, feed and nozzle size.

This is a parametric clone of the well-known BILLY Bookcase from Swedish international home products company IKEA.
TODO: holes for holding shelves bolts

• Download the openscad file.
  • Adjust the variables at the start of the file to create your preferred dimensions and style of Parametric BILLY Bookcase
  • Export the stl to your favourite slicer and print / cut.
    • Variables General
    width â†’ total width
    height â†’ total height
    depth â†’ total depth
    pthick â†’ Planks thickness
    shelves â†’ Number of shelves, including the top one but not the bottom one. It matches the number of gaps between shelves Skirting board
    A skirting board or baseboard is a board covering the lowest part of a interior wall. In presence of a skirting board, most pieces of furniture need a gap in order to keep it close to the wall
    skirting â†’ you can choose wether to use a gap to avoid skirting boards (true/false)
    sbdepth â†’ skirting board depth
    sbheight â†’ skirting board height Back plank
    Back planks are usually made out of plywood
    back â†’ you can choose wether to use a back panel (true/false)
    bthick â†’ back plank thickness

Your source is not a valid source, It is a student review of a book (not an expert source).
Please use this one, http://academic.eb.com/levels/collegiate/article/Andrew-Johnson/43849
**For Role and action, see my notes below

Mystery Artifact created by Andrew Nicastro

It’s a gravestone.
This gravestone is located in Tennessee.
“His faith in the people never wavered”.

The Object:
A Gravestone

Details about the Object:
The object is a statue with a square base that has an opening underneath almost like arches, on top of the square base is a pencil like object that extends straight up, at the top of the pencil like object there is an eagle. The whole statue is a significant link to the president, At the top of the statue there’s something missing which is an American flag draped over the top just under the eagle.

President:
Andrew Johnson,
17th president who served from 1865-1869
Andrew Johnson was a Democrat.

Either
"Faith in the people"-> pardon and amnesty confederate soldiers

OR
Constitution, (got impeached which involves the constitution)
Veto REconstration bills, or Becoming President post assassination, OR Impeachment

Presidential Role:

Executive Action:
Andrew Johnson decided to not focus on reconstruction, instead he focused on making life harder for slaves. Andrew Johnson negatively contributed a plan for reconstruction which failed.
“During Reconstruction, a lack of political focus on the effort failed to solve the sectional wounds, and the elimination of the freed slaves' newly gained civil liberties failed to bring about long-term racial integration.” (LitPick)

Impact on America:
This is important to American history because Johnson's reconstruction plan impacted many people. This object doesn’t directly represent a symbol of reconstruction but the object directly relates to Johnson himself.

Works Cited

LitPick/Flamingnet Teen Book Reviews. (n.d.). Retrieved March 01, 2017, from https://litpick.com/flamingnet.com/reconstruction.php

description.text:
This CNC machine the easiest and cheapest way to get into the magical world of Computer Numeric Control.
It is designed to have minimal parts requirements, no support material, Fast print times, and very "Forgiving" in case of programming error.
If you are familiar with DIY CNC machines, you know they have the tendency to be... self destructive.
This design allows for ZERO damage if there is unexpected twisting, over shooting, and even if say you have to slam on the brakes and it flies across the mini van.
So if you are new, it is good to learn the ins and outs, before you leap into an expensive model.

comments.text: Printed rails and gantry don't seem like they'd be very strong. What materials can/can't this machine?
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text:
Interesting observation, although the rails are printed in ABS plastic they are surprisingly rigid for a couple of reasons. The gantry rails have a similar cross-section of an I-beam, where the vertical side rails act as a web and horizontal backing acts as the flange. In addition to the internal structure, the Y-axis is attached with the clamps to the waste board and then takes on the rigidity of the board. The X-Axis has some flex in it, which is purposefully. If you are new and learning on how to control the CNC, making mistakes is part of process and having a "forgiving" machine that can flex and bend without permanent damage can be very useful.
Because the Z-axis is still a work in progress I have limited test materials to reference, but I have hooked up a laser with great results, an extruder (which did a test pattern with .1 mm accuracy), pens/pencils (same test pattern), and a little rotary tool from Harbor Freight ( I used electrical tape to attach the router so it was a bit wiggly).
I'll have more videos and reference material on cutting speeds by the end of the weekend.
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Hey thanks for your quick and detailed reply :) I guess my concern was force when routing thru materials. A laser or plastic extruder would be fine as they just have to carry the weight of the tool. I'm interested to hear how material tests with a routing bit go. Obviously this thing isn't going to mill 6mm aluminium in one cut, but I guess foam will be okay, and a 1mm pass thru MDF would probably make it fairly useful. Good luck and keep us posted!
comments.author: EasilyBuild

comments.text:
I'm actually not that worried about the rights of the material. Especially on X axis, as the rails are fully supported by the base plate.
But to get a practical CNC router, I recommend massively reducing Z height. As low as you can go, like 25mm or lower. This would reduces the rotational force affecting the gantry massively.
We have also had success in making the gantry axis horizontal and milling through an opening in the center, further reducing the rotational force vector on gantry. https://github.com/fellesverkstedet/fabricatable-machines/blob/master/award-plotter/img/28Testing-reproduction-by-milling-new-Z-axis.JPG
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Oh I like that design! Ya I think you're right about the height of the Z-Axis. I played around with putting the motor on the back and lower, but the setup has so much gear, pulleys, ect. the added weight offset the lower center of gravity. The home depot screw I have kind of wobbles so I was thinking about using a threadless ball screw. Have you ever played around with one of those?

title: FolgerTech 2020 i3 Y Axis Belt Holder and Tensioner

description.text:
The original FolgerTech Y axis belt holder didn't line up very well with the idler and motor. I remixed FolgerTech's design and added the ability to adjust Y belt tension.

Changes:

  • Added material between the "teeth" that engage the belt for more strength.
  • Lowered the belt away from the bed several mm to bring it closer in line with the motor and idler.
  • Separated into two pieces so that the belt could be assembled with a convenient amount of slack, yet still have adjustable tension when fully assembled.

Adjustment is a little annoying since it can be awkward to get the hex wrench on the adjustment screw. However, this does not have to be done very often, so to me it is an acceptable trade for adjustability.

Installation

Install this in place of the FolgerTech version, placing the Red end towards the rear of the printer. Install an M3 nylock nut in the red part and a long M3 Socket Head Cap Screw and washer in the green part. Bolt the green part to the bed plate, but leave the red part free for now.

Push each end of the belt into the mount ends and route the belt around the motor pulley and idler. Bring the red end of the mount and screw the adjuster in a couple of threads. Squeeze the mount parts together to verify that you have just the right amount of slack. If necessary, move the belt on the mount so that you have enough slack to allow the adjuster screw to thread into the nylock, but not so much that you run out of adjustment.

Then just tighten the belt to tension and re-adjust after making a few prints to ensure good belt tension.

This is the new version of toplar_rulman from Nevit Dilmen.
This parts is made with seven balls and the value to change is the diameter of axis.
All the other features are recalculated.
In version4, I corrected some errors in particular in the formula of the radius of the ball.
I also modified my approach to the drawing, starting from a 2d shape to be extruded.
And especially I added the spacers between the ball cages.

From the diameter of axis and the thickness of the inner ring, I calculate the radius of the ball.
To do this, you have to know the constraint of ball bearing mounting with seven balls. Five balls are held in a half circle.
So the formula is
sine(180/10)*(radius of axis + thickness of inner ring)/(1-sine(180/10)
The constant values are

  • the thickness of inner ring (and outer ring)
  • the thickness of clips and hook of clips
  • the thickness of ball cage
  • the play

Change the diameter of axis and a new ball bearing appears.
You can change the constant values too. There is no issues with the thickness of inner ring but the other constant values are constraint by the size of bearing. (i.e. if you let thickness of clips to 2 for a diameter of axis to 4, it will be a issue).
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b8NOGOu6PEF

comments.author: Shadowkon

comments.text:
I do agree with MKSA, restricting the ends of the threaded rods is in detriment of the quality.
The rod has been left loose to avoid the eccentric movement of the threaded rod to apply force to the smooth rod.
Thats why Anet engineers also used the acne type thread, really loose.
Because the threaded rods and smooth rods are not perfectly parallel and in the same plane exactly, when you restrict wobbling,
the middle of the threaded rod will be wobbling but you will not be able to see that. e.g. if the threaded rod wants to wobble to the right, if restricted, will exert force to the smooth rod to the left, if it want to move to the back, will exert force to the front.
Think of it like when you rotate and archers weapon, if you hold the two end and you rotate it, what happens to the middle of the arch?

title: FolgerTech 2020 Y Axis Idler Bearing Holder

description.text:
I didn't like Folgertech's Y-axis idler pulley design for their 2020 i3 printer. It was fiddly to assemble the bearings, washers and angle brackets, and the resulting assembly carried the belt a couple of mm higher than the motor pinion. So I designed this.

Required:

  • M5 X 25 hex-head bolt
  • M5 Nylock nut and washer
  • 2 5 x 10 x 4 flanged ball bearings

Installation:

  • Wrap the belt around the two flanged bearings, with the flanges on the outside to act as belt guides
  • Run the bolt into the mount, through the bearings, so that its head sits in the hex pocket on the side of the mount.
  • Put the washer over the bolt and thread on the Nylock
  • Attach the holder to the 2020 frame with M5 bolts and T-nuts.
  • Tension your Y-axis belt.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Supports:

No

Notes:

If printed as shown in the STL viewer, this will not require any supports. However, I would recommend a brim.

Also, you will want to have VERY GOOD layer adhesion, or else this'll pull right apart once you add some belt tension.

author: JWag

description.text: Unlike 3d printed ties that are hinged and move unnaturally, this design drapes more like cloth by using hexagons strung together with thread.  Use different color hexes to create patterns!

NOTE:I recommend using mono-filament or cloth thread to string everything together.  Purists can use ABS thread, but the tie will be more fragile.  See the bottom note for how to make ABS thread.  From here on, we'll just call it all "thread".   
The parts are sized in multiples of .4mm, so you may get best results with .2mm or .4mm layer height printing.  Since only the flat surface is visible, additional resolution doesn't really add anything other than time.   
1) Figure out how long of a tie you want to make in cm.  Divide by 2, and that's how many hexes you should print for the center column.  E.g., for a 44cm tie, print 22 hexes for the center column.  
2) Figure out how you want the "fat part" of the tie to look.  You will probably want 2 columns on either side of the center column, with some taper (see pictures).  Estimate the number of hexes you will need for one side (I used a column of 13, and an outer column of 3 on each side for a total of 26) and print that many.  Arrange the results on a flat surface to verify the count, adjust as necessary, and print enough for the other side.  
3) Arrange the tie hexes in the shape you want, FLAT SIDE DOWN.  Don't forget about the half-hexes, which usually start & end the side-columns.  Note that the bottom edge of the tie should be a flat side of the hex, not a hex point.   Count the number of places that you could put a half hex around the edge and print that many half-hexes.  If you followed my design above, you will need 8 (4 per side).  
4) Tie your thread to the flat edge of one hex using a good knot, and run the thread up through the center column of hexes.  Leave plenty of extra thread at the top, so you can tie it to the hub piece, later.  Loop the thread through the last hex loop a few times just to hold things in place.  DO NOT pull the thread super tight, leave it a little loose so the tie can flex.  
5)   Thread the side columns in the same manner.  When they're done, place them side-by-side (so your tie is face down), and thread them together back & forth through the side loops on the hexes.  
6) Put on a dress shirt and measure around your neck in cm with the collar up.  Divide by two and that is how many square pieces you will need.  Print 4 solids and the rest hollow to save plastic, plus the two clips (end pieces).  
7) Arrange the neck pieces, FLAT SIDE DOWN on a flat surface.  Clip, two solids, the hollows, two solids, clip.  Tie your thread do the clip loops, thread through all the pieces, and tie a temporary knot on the other end (so you can undo to add/remove pieces if needed).  Do the top & bottom with separate threads, just in case.  
8)  Print the center hub and the hex column.  Glue the hex column to the center of the flat side of the hub (using acetone, if available), so that the points of the column are pointing at the flat edges of the hub (ie, rotate the column 30 degrees with respect to the hub).  In other words, the column should be on the opposite side of the hex that has the block with three holes.   The points on the hex column should be pointing up and down relative to the tie.  
8) Try on the neck strap.  The two ends should snap into the center hub at an angle, so the straps + tie make a Y shape (see pictures).  If it is too tight or too loose, add/remove pieces as necessary.  When it's right, redo the temporary knot with a permanent knot.  Note that the hub should be closest to your neck, with the column facing out.  
9)   Use temporary knots to tie the tie to the hub. Check the length of the tie.  If it's not right, then adjust as necessary by adding/removing hexes at the top. When you are satisfied put in the permanent knots.   
10) Print the tie cover, flat side down.  It snaps over the hex column, and is meant to resemble the tie knot.  Congratulations, you are done!  
For more interesting ties, use different color hexes and make a pattern!  
Appendix: If you want to be a purist and have the entire thing be ABS (see the last photo!), then you can make ABS thread to use in place of thread.  Do this by raising your print head high enough so you can easily reach in under it.  Set your printer to extrude a lot of filament (30mm?) .  As the filament starts to come out, grab the end and pull gently at a constant rate.  The idea is to make a thin thread that is of uniform thickness.  You may have to experiment before you get the right thickness, but when you have it, it should be flexible enough to tie into a small knot, yet strong enough to hold the weight of the hexes.  Note that using mono-filament will result in a SIGNIFICANTLY stronger tie.  Having done both, I recommend the mono-filament approach.

comments.text: Yes, should be fine.  .2 might give better results, though.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text:
What makes the coarser layer height better? Most people are going to have a .4 or .5 mm nozzle giving almost round extrusion and not much contact between layers.
Better because of print speed or some type of durability?
comments.author: cahorton

comments.text: Since the visible part (other than the tie "knot") is composed entirely of the layer touching your print bed, adding layers doesn't improve the appearance, it just adds to the print time.  I haven't seen any evidence of layer adhesion problems and I print at .4 all the time (again, mainly for speed purposes).  Again, there's no harm in printing with more layers, it just adds time.  The sizes are multiples of .4 or .2, however, thus my recommendation.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I have found even that increasing layer height for the first layer makes the bottoms look nicer since I can "squash" them down a little farther causing it to fill in any gaps. You could probably do this by over extruding for the first layer too.
comments.author: cahorton

comments.text: Laywood would be interesting!  My first print was a little too high so I ended up with stripes and that looked cool.  During my second tie print, my kapton tape was not in good shape, so the tiles came out looking "pre-distressed".  Now that my tape is new, I want to do a 3rd print with different colors, so the tiles are smooth.

description.text:
I was planning on going to a networking session here in KC last week, but then I realized I've got some pretty lousy business cards. I figured I would try and make an awesome functional business card in time for the event that would make a good first impression. I came up with this 3.5"x2" card that snaps apart and forms a very functional rubber band gun! Video of the card in action here:
http://youtu.be/InnUcXhVeN0

Cut out of 0.06" thick Delrin or acetal. If you add your own vector etching, I've found that you can add color to your etching by saturating the etching with a dry erase marker and wiping off the excess. As for the actual assembly and opperation of the cards, follow the handy instruction sheet! I'm going to make up some regular business cards with the instructions printed on them to destribute with the cards as well. Currently it uses #10 or smaller rubber bands, which are a little hard to come by locally, but there's plenty of places to get them online, including McMaster if you're ordering plastic for these. Also, feel free to contact me if you want some custom ones made at [email protected]! Update:
Get your own here: http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/products/330223-rubber-band-business-card Another Update:
I've uploaded a "rev b" version with a much better spring mechanism and easier to insert clips.

remixed_from.author: Stonedge
remixed_from.title: Dual Action OTF Hidden Blade (Assassin Style)

description.text:
Huge credit and thank you to Stonedge for the internals of the hidden blade and the basis of this design. This blade would not be possible without him!

With that said this is my rendition of the hidden blade utilising Ezio's design from each of his games rather than the standard assassin blade along with the wheel and casing design seen on Giovanni's hidden blade during lineage.

Be warned that this project can be incredibly difficult to build and although I have tried my best to help you may run into a few roadblocks such as sourcing non-printed parts.

Step Zero - Non Printed Parts and Printing Advice

The only crucial piece of printing advice is that the outer blade locks must be printed in an orientation where the holes are not facing the sky, most 0.4mm printers cannot complete this shape if they are where as they can otherwise.

If you are finding the inner blade does not lock very well try the extra strength locks and if the wheel doesn't return or gets stuck replace the gear with the thicker version.

As for parts, you will need (with inclusions of where you can get some in the UK):

  • Two regular rubber bands (staples)

  • Three no.8 size rubber bands (amazon)

  • One extra small clear hairband (claire's)

  • One small clear hairband (claire's)

  • Nylon cord (homebase)

  • Six 20mm length M3 screws (screwfix)

  • One 2.75mm diameter spring which will need to be cut to length (RS components)

  • One regular size paper clip (staples)

  • Some super glue (any supermarket)
Step One - The Blade

We'll start with the blade itself, for this you will need:

  • Two copies of the inner blade

  • The outer blade bottom

  • The outer blade top

  • Two copies if the outer blade locks

  • Small clear hairband

  • Paperclip

  • Superglue

Begin by first taking the two halves of the inner blade and gluing them back to back, make sure that they are in alignment with each other before letting the glue set and be sure to remove any excess glue. Once this is done take the inner blade and insert it into the bottom half of the outer blade, place the top half on top and hold the the two together gently. If the inner blade sticks and doesn't move freely then sand down the top and bottom of the blade until it moves under gravity.

Once you are certain that the inner blade is thin enough it's time to assemble the blade, first you'll need to measure the thickness of your two outer blade pieces together and cut a length of metal from your paper clip long enough to be inserted through both halves but not long enough to stick out too far. Insert each piece into each hole on the bottom of the outer blade making sure they will stay in place firmly, if they do not use a small amount of super glue to make sure they do. You can now insert the metal pins through the holes of your outer blade locks, they should rotate freely once attached.

Now you are able to attach the top half of the outer blade, again inserting the pins through their accompanying holes, and attach the clear hairband to the channel along the outer blade. Getting the elastic behind the locks can prove tricky, I find the easiest way is to separate the halves and remove the inner blade, this allows the locks to be rotated out of the way so you can position the elastic before placing everything back. Finally, once everything is in place your inner blade should move freely while the locks are open and stay completely extended when they are engaged. If this is the case you can now carefully glue the outer halves together making sure no glue falls inside, don't forget to remove any excess glue from the outside too.

Step Two - The Main Body

For the main body of the hidden blade you will need:

  • Main body

  • Front blocker

  • The blade from step one

  • Four copies of the main lock

  • Switch plate

  • Two copies of the switch plate carriage

  • Middle body

  • Two no.8 rubber bands

  • Two regular rubber bands

Start off by taking the front blocker and placing it in the front of the main body, the curve of the front blocker should align with the curve of the main body, this can now be glued into place. Next take the blade from earlier and insert it into the casing, the locks may need to be pressed in while you do this. Once inside we can begin to construct the switch plate, each side of the switch plate will have a small channel which the carriages will slot into, in order to make these carriages functional however you will need to insert a regular rubber band into each of the carriages as shown in the video. Once this is complete insert the switch plate into the main body on top of the blade with the gap in the plate at the back of the main body and make sure that the clear hairband does not get caught on the switch plate at any point, if it does you'll have to sand down the area it is catching on.

You've just completed the bulk of the hidden blade, now you just need to make it work. To do so take each of your four main locks and place them in their corresponding holes around the main body, the hook of each lock should be pointing upwards. Place the middle plate on top of the main body and make sure that the locks enter the holes of the middle body without leaving the main body's. Once done you should be able to affix a no.8 elastic band between each pair of locks and test that your blade is working, to do this simply move the gap on the switch plate from one side of the hole in the middle body to the other and monitor the result. If the blade does not fully extend or retract then you need to sand it down further.

Step Three - The Wheel

For this step you will need:

  • The construction from step two

  • Wheel

  • Wheel Pivot

  • Wheel lock

  • Gear

  • Two copies of the gear lock

  • Rack

  • Ring

  • Extra small clear hairband

  • No.8 rubber band

  • 2.75mm spring

  • Nylon cord

For this step you'll want to begin by taking the wheel pivot and gluing it into the wheel with the pivot extending out of the flat side of the wheel. Once this is done take the wheel lock and insert it along the channel in the middle body, make sure that the flat side of the lock is facing the side of the wheel you don't want to turn, for a left handed blade this would be in the clockwise direction. Once in place use the extra small clear hairband to secure it in place along each of the three pegs, if done right your wheel lock should be able to be pressed inward and then spring back out. Now your wheel can be inserted making sure that the lock slots into the notch in the wheel.

With the wheel out of the way let's get started on the gear, to start take each of your two gear locks and insert them into the channels on the top of the wheel, their flat sides should face in the opposite direction of the wheel lock. Now we need to add a spring in-between these locks so they can be pressed in, to do this take your 2.75mm spring and cut it to a length where it can be placed in between the two locks and press them outwards. The length of this spring is a very crucial point, if the spring is too long then the locks will be too strong and won't retract, if the spring is too short then the locks will be too weak and will skip while being used. The correct length can vary based upon the quality of your print.

When you are happy with the length of your spring insert it between the two gear locks. Once this is done take your final no.8 rubber band and insert it through the gap in the back of your rack, as for the gap in the front that is where your nylon cord will go, simply insert a length of cord through the gap and then tie it in place. The rack will then lie in place along one side of the middle plate, for a left handed blade use the right side of the blade, with the elastic placed around the corresponding peg. Once in place insert the other end of your cord through the hole of your ring and find a length at which you can wear the ring and pull the rack from one side of it's channel to the other while the hidden blade is on your arm. When you find the perfect length tie the cord there and cut away any excess.

Finally take the gear and insert it over the wheel so that it interlocks with the rack and the notches in the gear line up with the gear locks.

Step Four - The Cover Plate

For this final step you will need:

  • Everything made in step three

  • The cover plate of your choice

  • Wheel filler

  • Wheel cover

  • Super glue

  • Six M3 20mm screws

If you prefer the hidden blade to not have a visible wheel on the exterior then simply lay the cover plate on top of the body and insert each of the six screws into each of the holes, congratulations you're done!

However if you prefer to have a wheel then there are a few more steps, to begin do the same as above but you'll only need two screws to keep the plate in the correct place. When done make sure that your gear is positioned in a central position and apply a small drop of glue to either side of the gear as far away from the locks as possible. Take your wheel filler and press it into the glue making sure that the notch in the centre is facing upwards and the filler is as central as you can possibly make it. When the glue dries it will be safer if you open the cover again and make sure that only the gear is glued to the filler. When you are sure this is the case replace the cover plate and glue your wheel cover to the top of the filler, the notch in the centre of the filler should slot into the cover to make sure it is in the right place. Once this is all dry you're done, your wheel should rotate as you pull on the cord and after you pull the cord to its fullest extend the blade will activate.

All you have left is to attach the hidden blade to your arm by your preferred method and have fun!

I printed everything out and sanded all the parts but i still have problems. There is something that prevent my blade from being fully retracted; the blade stuck in the middle while retracting. Look like the main locks are the reason because they block the blade. The blade is also too heavy to be retracted in the opposite direction of gravity.
Indeed, the hardest part is gathering rubber bands and spring. I cant find that spring so i have to make a new wheel and use wheel mechanism like other hidden blades

comments.text: The locks shouldn’t get in the way, the switchplate will hold the currently used locks open while the blade is moving and the opposing locks will be pushed open by the blade. Perhaps the elastic you are using is too strong?
comments.author: TD123

comments.text: you are correct, the elastic bands are too strong. I replaced them with larger radius elastic bands and I have no problem now. Furthermore, the small spring for the wheel could be found in most cheap cigarette lighters. Thanks for the hidden blade! this is one of the best things I have printed so far.

author: zpride

description.text:
I did like the orginal Vise from "The Goofy" very much, but I could not print the Threads good enough. The Nut would not insert into the Rod.
This is why I had some Metal Parts included instead. Now it works like a charm

Parts

  • 2 M12 Nuts
  • 2 M12 Rod with 102 mm of length
  • 2 Main Gears(2)
  • 1 Sliding Jaw(2)
  • The Remaining parts from the original Vise: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064269

Instructions

  • Print the Parts
  • Cut the Threads
  • Form a nice Thread into the new Sliding Jaw. Make sure to get a perfect 90deg angle
    ( I used a Drill rig)
  • Glue and insert the Rods into the Sliding Jaw
  • Insert the Nuts into Main Gear
  • Assemble rest of the Vise from the original instructions.

Happy Tooling!

description.text:
To be honest: On Lemm's original design there is next to nothing left to desire.
I created this remix to publish my Eagle files replacing the perfboard. (I hate perfboards ;-) ). SMD was preferred over thru-hole parts because I use them for most of my designs. Copies of that board can be ordered easilly and reasonably priced at https://www.oshpark.com/
On the design side I took the liberty of just increasing the thickness of the mounting plate since the original design seemed a bit flimsy to me at that point.

print_settings.Notes:: Print part 2 times in a row and NOT together during one print to avoid any difference in print or resulting from slight bed bendings or bad calibration. High of helper doesn't matter as long as they are identical. It is made to clip on 8mm guide tubes.

description.text:
I made this small tool to help balancing Z axis.
It was too complicated to measure high of Z axis on both sides and find same high for both.
So Now I just Clip this Thing on both Z axis guides and move down Z axis until stepper Motors start ratter and move them up again.

after this, both axis sides have exact same high and no additional measure needed.

author: LittleDiver65

description.text:
This is a lightpainting tool designed to fit the universal connector by Jason D. Page found on https://lightpaintingbrushes.com/.

There are two versions of this tool, one is designed to have a brightness gradient along its length, the other one is designed to create a homogeneous light bar. You can enhance the effect by covering the inside with tin foil before mounting the diffuser. I included two versions of the diffuser, one to be printed with the right shape, the other one to be printed flat and bend into shape after printing. If you can print the pre-shaped one it will perform better.

In the example photos the green one is made with the gradient tool, the blue one without gradient.

Somehow the CAD program I use has different axes then 3D printers, so the models need to be rotated. Cases are supposed to be printed on the back like you can see in the fist photo. The flat diffuser is supposed to be printed flat on the bed.

title: REmixed Prusa MK2 Threaded Bearing Spool holder w/filament guide

description.text:
Remix from two other spool holders and slightly modified. Main holder rides on two internal bearings for a nice smooth roll. Can accommodate several spool sizes.

UPDATE: Added new Spool Main assembly (v2) that beefs up the arm as well as where the nut inserts. If you're planning on printing this out of PLA, I would recommend going V2 over the original.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-50

Notes:

If your slicer has a "Supports from build plate only" option, turn that on.

BOM

You'll need some additional hardware to assemble this:

3 x M8 nuts. (5/16th also works) - http://amzn.to/2hdztwf
Some 8mm threadded rod. (5/16th also works) - http://amzn.to/2gNYK2V
2x 608ZZ bearings.- http://amzn.to/2g6naFQ

Assembly

Attach the threaded rod to the main arm assembly, with a nut in back and a nut in front, securing the rod to the arm.

Push a 608 bearing into each side of the inner spool threaded assembly. Slide assembly onto threaded rod and secure loosely into place with another nut.

Assembly Video

Optional Steps

I like to sand down the grips on the spool holder as they can be semi sharp off the bed. 600-800 grit sandpaper around the edge of the grips helps.

title: MK7 Filament tube support - modified to be taller

description.text: Modified barspin's nice MK7 filament tube support to be a little taller to make it stronger and see the filament entering the MK7.

Print with a fairly high infill (say 30-40%) in order to be somewhat strong and clip strongly to the MK7.  Depending on which rod cover position is used for your spool and which one might be used for a tube guide, the tube may be oriented more or less vertically when reaching down into the TOM toward the extruder.  If the tube is angled, the guide will probably slip some away from being vertical, but it should continue to perform.

title: Guardian Scout Nintendo Switch Cartridge Holder

description.text:
This is my entry for the Nintendo Switch Design Challenge on MyMiniFactory (https://www.myminifactory.com/object/30150). I modelled this after the Guardian Scouts from The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. It is designed to hold 4 Nintendo Switch cartridges.

I made this to complement my other project, the Guardian Stand for the Nintendo Switch (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2181119). In the game, the scouts extend their neck and head to reveal an array of weapons. Rather than weapons, I wanted to show an array of video games! In the near future, and when I have the time, I'd love to create a version where the games are hidden inside the main body, and you need to lift up the head/neck to reveal the contents.

This was 100% modelled from scratch. I did not use any scans of amiibo or any in-game models to create this model.

Notes on printing:

  • Supports are required

  • I did not use infill

  • Took about 10 hours on the M3D Micro on Medium Quality / Thick wall, no infill settings

Printer:

M3D Micro

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

None

comments.text: Nice job
comments.author: ChunkAhoy

comments.text:
You can certainly sand before painting, but for parts like these where there's a lot of smaller parts and grooves, I just use a Rust-oleum Sandable Primer Filler. It makes the print a lot smoother and removes most of the visible layers. Although too much can start removing the details from the print as well...
After, I just used silver metallic spray paint on the legs, and used regular cheap acrylic paint for the rest of the painting. I use a product called Varathane Polyurethane (water based, comes in gloss, semi-gloss, or matte but I read gloss is more reliable). It's meant sealing wood, but many people use it on polymer clay and I figured I'd try it on 3D prints and it works fine for me.

author: jaedoel

title: Cable chain anchor mounts for D-bot

description.text:
This is a frame mount and a carriage plate mount for a large cable chain to be mounted on my D-bot. The chain is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951006 which I printed at 60% scaling, which is still quite large.

The carriage plate mount mounts onto the carriage plate via the two M3 screw holes the original D-bot carriage plate provides for mounting a little thing to secure the end of a 1/2" conduit with the bowden tube and wiring. Instead of this little conduit mount, attach my mount. Attach the frame mount onto the front top rail of the D-bot.

I printed these out of PETG, fairly slowly. I used a thick, .6mm nozzle, and used several perimeters to make them very stiff. Exact settings will be up to the individual and their printer to decide, but my recommendation is to make them stiff and strong.

comments.text: frame_cable_snake_anchor does not appear to be exported to STL properly based on it's size when opened in a slicer.

comments.text: That's really odd. Something I'd changed in Solidworks while working on a different part also changed how this one was exported. I've fixed it and tested it in S3D and Cura on my machine, and it seems to work fine now. Try it again and see if it's working for you.

title: Harbor Freight Dial Indicator Holder for Chimera Mount

description.text:
I was having a hard time tuning my first delta printer, an He3d K200. I wanted to mount a dial indicator, but all I could find were ones designed for single hotends. I have a dual - the hole patterns are different. I found a mount that looked good and remixed it here to mount onto the effector. You do have to remove the hot end to use this, but it puts the dial indicator pretty close to center. You also have to change your z max height, so it can go low enough to reach the bed.

This was designed for my K200, but should work with any printer where you have access to mount above where the hot end goes, and that will let the bed get close enough (that would probably include most deltas, but not necessarily most cartesians.

comments.text: Very clever.

I wanted a very strong and compact bracket for securely mounting one piece of 2020 aluminum extrusion to another piece along its side.

If that's not described clearly then just look at the pictures. This assumes that the end of the overlapping piece will be flush with the side of the other piece, and that the hole in the center of that extrusion is tapped for an M5 screw.

I designed this because I had a length of 2020 extrusion that I wished to hang off the side of my D-bot to mount my extruders on, and I wanted it to be strong and stiff.

In the photos you see instances of these corner brackets printed out in carbon fiber/PETG. This is not necessary, but I wanted to try it out. It's extremely stiff.

Link to blog post with more pictures and a short write-up

https://tt3d.xyz/2017/03/17/switch-lasering-complete/

This is a Corel Draw File template that outlines the boundaries of the NORTH AMERICAN SWITCH (There is s different silkscreen layout for other regions so be careful) Just place your images on the layer that is named "Place your images on this layer" and the boundary layer will do the masking off where it should not cut. If your laser is aligned properly, you just place it your Switch face down, text reading correctly, at 0,0 on the bed.

suggested power on an Epilog 40W CO2 laser is speed 50%, power 12% but feel free to experiment. Make sure to turn vector cut OFF!

Also attached is a .DWG file to import into other image programs of your choice

Make sure to NOT VECTOR CUT when using the laser as that will slice your switch

title: S4 Mini Reinforced case for flex filament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The lack of full circumference in top layers was causing the original design to be non-working with flex filaments like rubber or Ninjaflex. I mean the case will not hold itself on the phone when printed from flex filament. I have added the bridges over the button openings to form "rigid" circumference - now it should work fine.

22MAR2017 UPDATE: case still not 100% compatible with S4 Mini for two reasons:

  1. the overlap is just too small to hold the phone.
  2. case currently has top and bottom identical radius - but S4Mini has actually larger blends on the bottom. This is just a minor, but in combination with point 1 makes the case not hold the phone correctly.

Solution: I need to oversize the top layer overlap by at least 2mm - inward - but with conventional printing it would be not printable as the internal perimeters will be printed purely in air. So a small trick to be used. Stay tuned for next remix.

title: large laptop stand (dell latitude, toshiba Satellite 15-17inch)

description.text:
This one fits for large heavy laptops. I use one for my Dell Latitude, my wife uses one for her Toshiba Satellite 17" ...
Made it in smaller pieces to be printed on smaller beds. The 2 hooks hold the parts together but a bit of cyanocrylate will fix it forever.
Both parts are connected with 3 x 4mm threaded rod with a 6mm brass tube to keep the parts at 270mm and to hide the threaded rods
Height of the hook is 26mm
I printed it in PLA with a 0,6mm nozzle at 0,4mm layerheight. 2 walls, 3 bottom, 3 top, 30% infill fast honeycomb,3600mm/min
You will have to clean up (a bit of filing) the locking part when using larger nozzles due to the wider tracks.

I added the S3D factory files as well
The 2 parts for one side should fit on a 200x200mm bed (see screenshot).

title: Isosurface Early Stage Companion Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Another isosurface, this time I think it's starting to look like the early stages of the evolution of the good old companion cube.

Printer:

Eaglemoss Vector3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I tried to get away without supports in my printed model, but some of the lower sections definitely could do with some.

I started with some code I give my students to help them start 3D graphics projects. This helps them create models in Vertex and Index Buffers programmatically. I then grabbed the Marching Cubes function from here, and used it so that I could feed in an equation and get out a Vertex Buffer containing a given iso-surface of that equation, display it and then spits out a basic obj file. I then fed the obj file my program produced from it into Netfabb to stitch it together, cut its bottom off to make sure it sat down firmly on the build plate and spit out an stl file.

This time I just sat playing with my code and fiddling with the equations I was passing into it until it produced an interesting object. Eventually I arrived at this, which I think looks like the early stages of the evolution of the Portal Weighted Companion Cube.

(cos(x) * cos(y) * cos(z) + fmod(x,1) * fmod(y,1) * fmod(z,1) * fmod(x, 1) * fmod(y, 1) * fmod(z, 1) - (x * x+y * y < 0.1 ) - (x * x + z * z < 0.1) - (z * z + y * y < 0.1)) * exp(-(x * x+y * y+z * z- PI * PI) ) = 0.7

In the region of [-Pi,Pi] along all axes.

remixed_from.author: ZestyTech
remixed_from.title: Mockup of the Zesty Nimble: Lightweight direct drive extruder

title: HE280 Zesty Nimble Hat (Rostock Max v3)

description.text:
Got my nimble! And it fits!

Finally. Got a working mount for the Zesty Nimble on SeeMeCNC's HE280/Rostock Max v3 hotend/printer.

I made a few designs before... each one realizing it interfered with something that i didnt have modeled. and another where i just made it too tall.

Anyway, here it is, step file included, once i get my nimble ill test fit it and post pics too.
Solidworks files available on request, but its a jumble of parts combined into assemblies back into parts/bodies, finally combined and cleaned up.

Best to print at .1mm layer height, pretty slow, and probably 100% infill.
Youll definitely want to print with support too. I set it pretty dense at 25% my first go at it. The bottom wont look the prettiest, but it will be hidden anyway.

19June2017

My nimble finally retracts!

Follow the documentation for the nimble to get it to work. I had changed the max start extrude rate, but... i had lowered the current too much, and the stepper didnt work, soooo. Yeah. My bad. Had i not touched the current, none of this would have happened.

9June2017

Added 3 more flies, this one with the hole for the PTFE tube to sit flush with the top surface, like every other nimble mount.
Originally i had designed it to jam the PTFE tube between this cover and the hotend, but hitting the exact PTFE tube length to prevent backlash/jams is hard. Cutting it flush is the better way.

I also have seemed to increase the STL export resolution/detail, so these recently uploaded files are much larger. FYI.

See 6June2017 for other info on bolt length.

6June2017

I got my nimble today! Yaaaay.
And, the mount works! Yaaay.
Set your extruder steps/mm to 2640.

However... Youll need to cut the included bolts down to make it fit. Booo.
The threaded lengths will need to be... 33mm and 36mm (per the model, i never measured myself). PLEASE PLEASE, TAKE CAUTION WHEN DOING THIS. Take off a little at a time, make sure the shorter one doesnt interfere with the fan headers, and repeat.

PTFE tube to be cut at 48mm, and youll need to take a ~4mm drill bit to clean the hole up for it (and maybe a small one for the filament path).
ORRR... you can drill that straight through and trim the PTFE tube off at the top, like every other nimble mount. (making a model like that now too)

And... Currently, Repetier firmware (for those using it) does not support the required settings for the nimble, specifically a very low extruder jerk value (1 mm/s). It is calculated internally using the max start feedrate. I believe this should be easy to patch, but im no c++ wizard, and havent had the ambition to edit the few files yet. So stay tuned.

But, i did have my first successful print with it, its a nimble mount for the Rostock Max V2, which is still being made, just trying some stuff out.

23Feb2017

After being unable to get my slicer to add supports as i wanted, i went ahead and added my own in solidworks. I ended up print half with my supports, half with slicer and while, mine took more time, they worked considerably better and snapped right off of the print with no need to scrape/clean up. So i painstakingly took the time to put supports under the rest of it. Ive attached 2 options, one with premade supports (for a .5mm nozzle), and another with the holes filled in so that youll get continuous support everywhere.

20Feb2017

Done, for the final time, I hope. Will print tomorrow and test fit. Basically the same as before, just a bit taller so the nut doesnt interfere with the fan plugs. Depending on the length of the hardware that comes with the nimble, it may need to be ground down a bit, as there is minimal clearance there. But it should all fit.

I also changed how the PTFE Tube sat, now its held down inside by the cap, so getting it cut to the correct length is crucial.
Pics (besides the render) are of the old one that doesnt actually fit, oh well, same concept.

19Feb2017

Printed tweaked version only to realize my model was still lacking and the piece interfered once i plugged the fan(s) in. ughhhhhh. Time for another full redesign.

18Feb2017

Printed and I realized there were a few thin spots, so it will still need some tweaks. Its also a bit too short on top of the hotend/PTC bit, so that needs to be cleaned up (but its supposed to be tight to hold the PTC fitting down, so the nimble can apply pressure to the PTFE Tube). Will update later/soon. Hopefully they get shipped out soon so I can actually get a test fit and tweak the design as needed.

Basically, see this: http://zestytechnology.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nimble_single/tuning.html

Set your EXT0_MAX_START_FEEDRATE to 1 in the firmware or through the PC with the EEPROM, or through the display.

Same goes for the acceleration.

Set your retract distance and speed in your slicer.

For V_ref/current... This one you may want to leave as is. I lowered mine substantially and it didnt work. But ill try tuning this around soon. It currently makes tons of noise when running, then again... i just picked a random 170/255 on the digipot and it worked.

description.text:
This is a car-holder to fit the HTC Touch-Pro in landscape-mode with the keyboard extended. Possible later improvements:
  • 0.2-0.5mm more space for the keyboard
  • 2x stronger back-plane (will get rid of the stringing too)
  • 2.5mm tapered cross-straps to strengthen the back
  • 50-66% thinner base-plate
  • 1.0mm wider hole for the cable
  • 60Â° instead of 45Â° angle for the taper on the lower side of the HAMA-mount

There are 2 versions of this one.
The basis-version contains no socket,
the HAMA-version can be attached to the car-holders (suction-cup, fan-grill, glue-on,...) by HAMA.

This is a cone with 608ZZ 22x7mm bearings in them. Print 2 of them and place your spool between them and the spool will turn very easy.
The cone starts at 70mm and goes to 30mm so you can use it for small spools and large spools. This was my first attempt to create something in Openscad so bear with me.

When i printed my first stuff, i didn't have a fan on my Mendel Prusa.
So i was afraid to bridge the gap above the bottom bearing. So when you print this, you will have to remove the thin wall cylinder that is in the lower bearing. I did this to make sure i could bridge the distance, without having the ceiling "collapse" and make sure the bearing fits. So after printing take a pair of pliers and remove / cut the very thin cylinder. The first one i printed i had it adjust on 22mm for the hole but the bearing was hard to fit, now i have made the hole for the bearring 22,5mm in diameter. Probably a lot could have been done different, but it works pretty well for me and i am quite happy and hope people can benefit from this ? UPDATE: Added the OpenSCAD file as requested by Arvin.

title: Filament Spool Roller using 608ZZ bearings - Snapped together and no bolts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I created this filament spool roller using 608zz bearings because I didn't like any of the ones out there and this also doesn't use any bolts. Everything snaps together. This was printed with ABS for strength and durability but you can also print this using PLA.

I've also include a new side and bottom base (Update 08-24-2017) for those whose want to use these spool rollers inside the Rubbermaid 21 cup dry food container for high moisture absorbing filaments. The Rubbermaid spool rollers were printed with yellow PETG.

Update 11-08-2017

  • Added OPTIONAL bearing roller guides to keep the spool centered on the bearings.
  • Added new pictures with these guides.

Update 08-24-2017

  • Some spools for the Rubbermaid 21 cup base did not roll properly because the roller sides were too thick (previous update). Added new sides to the rollers that are 2mm thinner (now 4mm thick)
  • Added also a new base to accommodate these new sides
  • Added new pictures and removed the other base/pictures for the Rubbermaid container

Update 08-18-2017

  • Added Rubbermaid 21 cup base so you can put the rollers in the dry storage container for Nylon or other high moisture absorbing filaments.
  • Added additional pictures with the Rubbermaid 21 cup base
  • Got the Rubbermaid storage here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BEUDWIC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Update 06-25-2017

  • Added CR-10 Base so you can mount one side of the rollers to case using the original screws provided by Creality
  • Added additional pictures with CR-10 base mounted/unmounted on the control box

Update 04-07-2017

  • As suggested by grantemsley, the pegs inside the base were removed for easier insertion of the sides.
  • Updated base model and removed old one.

Update 03-24-2017

  • Ran into a vendor who filled the filament to the outer rim of the spool and the rollers had difficulties spinning.
  • Increased the radius of the spool curve and removed old models to just one final model, bottom and side. (The old bottom works, just the side has changed)
  • Uploaded picture of final model (in white)

Update 03-19-2017

  • Uploaded a side model that ONLY has the fillet removed on the bottom for "cleaner lines" with nothing else has changed. You decide which "look" works for you, flat or fillet bottom line.

Parts list:

  • Bearing 608ZZ 8x22x7 : https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBD6X4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Printer:

FLSUN Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

30%

1. Take measurements of the cap height, cap diameter, and landscaping nail diameter. Puch those into Customizer/OpenSCAD file.
  2. Render/Export.
  3. Print with supports. You should only need them for the overhang for the cap.

Alternatively, pick the closest of the STLs, and scale it to your specific needs. X and Y must be scaled by the same amount, although Z can be scaled separately.

1. Remove supports.
  2. With a nail or drill bit, make a hole in the cap of your bottle.
  3. Place glue (anything waterproof: Wood Glue, silicone caulk, Goop, superglue gel, PVC pipe cement, avoid: white/PVA/school glue, gorilla glue, might work: tacky glue, contact cement) on sides of cap, base overhang (not in the funnel), and on sides of the cap recess in the base.
  4. Place cap into the base, swirl around so you have an even distribution of glue in the gap between the cap and the base. Wipe away excess glue with a damp paper towel/napkin/tissue.
  5. Turn upside down onto some Saran wrap or aluminum foil, wipe away excess glue with a damp paper towel/napkin/tissue, and allow the glue to cure per manufacturers instructions.
  6. Remove the base from your drying sheet.
  7. Place the base, cone side down, near the plant you want to water. It should be close enough to the plant, that the water will go to the roots, but far enough away that you can (un)screw the bottle from the base without interfering with the plant as it grows.
  8. Fit the landscaping nails into the holes in the nacelles, and happer them into the ground, making sure the base is level.
  9. Fill the bottle with water.
  10. Turn the bottle over and screw it into the base.

1. How does it work? As the soil dries out, water from the bottle will displace air in the soil, and water the soil. When the soil is saturated, there will be no air to bubble up the bottle and displace water in the bottle. If the seal between the bottle and the cap is air tight, this should keep the soil at a constant moisture.
  2. It's not working, no water is coming out. Either you forgot to tap a hole in the cap, or glue clogged the funnel. Drill a hole from the cap to the tip.
  3. It's not working, there is a small wet patch, but the plant isn't getting it. Your plant could be too far away (>12”), the hole in your cap could be too small, or your soil has too much clay in it.
  4. Water spills out the top of the base. The seal between the cap and the bottle is not good enough. Try screwing it down a bit more, maybe there is some dirt at the bottom of the cap, that prevents a good seal. Maybe your cap has cracked or deformed.
  5. I don't drink liquor or soda, because I am a wino. How can I get this to work? I cant help you if you drink boxed wine (although BotaBox is better than Franzia). For wine bottles, maybe try to increase the “cap_height” to something like 3 inches. Measure the width of the bottle at this distance down the neck, add 2-4 mm to this. Set this number to the “cap diameter”. Print the base per steps 1-4. Coat the top of the bottle and the neck with Silicone caulk to create a waterproof O-ring. Allow to dry separately from the base. Once dry, using a very sharp utility knife, cut away excess silicone so that the bottle makes a perfect flat seal with the base. The water will leak out if the bottle gets tilted, allowing air into the base.
  6. It's august, my cap is leaking, and it looks all deformed, what happened? You were probably using PLA, not ABS. PLA deforms at a relatively low temperature.

title: Raspberry Pi case to mate with PiPiece

description.text:
I took thing:16104 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16104 from HansH and added studs under the rasberry pi PCB for Model B Rev 2 mounting holes. On the top of the case, I added a slot and holes to mount thing:181310 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:181310 PiPiece by dmpalmer. This makes a very nice camera unit for mounting to my telescope when combined with the RaspberryPi and pi camera. I have submitted the STL's for printing at the Edmonton Public LIbrary's new MakerSpace http://www.epl.ca/makerspace, but there is quite a queue ahead of me, so it will be a while before I can confirm the print is good and I got the dimensions right. description.text:
Boitier permettant d’intégrer un switch opto. Se fixe sur une tige de 8mm de votre Dagoma DiscoEasy 200 avec l'option écran.

Principe :
L'opto detecte qu'il n'y à plus de filament.
L'imprimante se met en pause et émet des bits jusqu'au changement de filament
La tete se positionne à l'extrémité du plateau
L'ecran affiche l'attente du changement de filament
Une fois le filament changé, il suffit de valider avec le bouton de l'écran pour poursuivre l'impression là où elle c'est arrêtée.

Matériel nécessaire :

Il vous faut un switch opto
Le G de l'opto est à connecter sur le ground (au milieu) de Z- de la MKS
Le + est à connecter sur D18 de Z- de la MKS
Le S sur le connecteur restant de Z-

Dans Configuration.h :


#define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR
#if ENABLED(FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR)
  #define FIL_RUNOUT_INVERTING false // set to true to invert the logic of the sensor.
  #define ENDSTOPPULLUP_FIL_RUNOUT // Uncomment to use internal pullup for filament runout pins if the sensor is defined.
  #define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SCRIPT "M600"
#endif

title: Tevo Tarantula lower handle extruder for flexible filaments
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
EDIT UPDATE
I've updated the design. you m\ay still need to make the ptfe tube bigger. Also put some lubricant where the pulley bearing fits in on the side of the walls. Also use a short piece of ptfe for the filament guide. This version (v2) gives much better prints. **

This is my version of a Flexible filament extruder mod as none were working for me. It replaces the bottom handle of the tevo extruder so a PTFE tube can be pushed through closer to the gear. This creates more support for the filament. A write up can be found here

http://3dminiprints.weebly.com/blog/printing-tpu-with-the-tevo-tarantula

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

75%

Notes:

Might have to bore the hole out for the filament feed.
You will also need a Pneumatic Straight Fitting Connector for 4mm OD tubing M6 6mm.
(it's the same as the tevo's one)
Also put some lubricant where the pulley bearing fits in on the side of the walls. and also use a short piece of ptfe for the filament guide

I used 75% infil but you can probably get away with less

Instructions

Thread the screws in and the Pneumatic Straight Fitting. Sand down the side walls so the bearing moves freely. Fit onto the extruder.

This is a stand to keep your 3D pen from burning stuff when you put it down. It also makes a nice little display if you want to show it off... it'll gently hug the pen with enough grip to keep it there.

No supports needed if you print it face-down.

I designed it to fit the "AIO Robotics Premium 3D Printing Pen" but the same pen seems to have a bunch of vendors / names. It's from a company called MKOEM.

Other pens (and other stuff) should fit too; the top of the slot is 17mm wide, tapering down to 14 at the bottom.

Enjoy!

description.text:
After fighting with tape measure, rulers, and curling filament trying to get the steps/mm correct for the extruder, I came up with this device. It is designed for the E3D V6, but I have included the OpenSCAD file to allow modifications for other hotend types.

To use this gauge, you need to remove your hotend and insert the gauge in its place. Feed a length of filament (can be a loose piece about 100mm in length) and align the leading edge with the very top at the zero mark. Enable cold extrusion and extrude a set amount. I used 50mm in the sample photos. The first picture shows that I actually got 53mm. Using the formula: Expected/Actual * current steps/mm = new steps/mm, I changed the configuration and reset the filament and extruded 50mm. This time I got exactly what I wanted (I had a feeling this printer was over extruding a bit).

The ruler I used is from Amazon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DB1C3QS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and I attached it to the gauge with some left over 3M 468MP adhesive sheets I had used to mount my print surface with (https://www.amazon.com/Gizmo-Dorks-Adhesive-Transfer-Sheets/dp/B01HP2CEG8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1489796419&sr=8-1&keywords=3m+high+temperature+adhesive+sheet).

There is a slot on one side of the tube where you can see the filament next to the ruler. You can use whatever type of ruler you want. If the metric side is on the opposite side of the ruler, you can use OpenSCAD to rotate the opening.

I printed this with eSun Natural PLA+ filament.

author: arivanbastos

description.text:
Using the same logic that created the soap bubble chair, I created a double sided vase whose shape could be formed with soap bubbles. A soap bubble evenly distributes curvature throughout its shape, but at the same time equally distributes the structural forces as well. If you could harness this property for a structural system, you could use recycled materials and yield the same strength as high performance steel.
I recently posted a Kickstarter campaign to support plan to build a real chair that uses these concepts. Please enjoy the soap bubble chair model posted earlier to Thingiverse, and I would encourage everyone who can to pledge a contribution on Kickstarter. My goal is to get 250 people to pledge $40. 
kickstarter.com/projects/1748240161/soap-bubble-chair
In the coming days and weeks I'll be posting more things that use these shaping techniques, so check back and enjoy. Or just follow me on Twitter at @mSurfaces for the announcements.

The model will need support material to print correctly. I used support material based upon Luke Chilson's blog post explaining how to create an according style support that rips off very easily by hand after the print. http://www.protoparadigm.com/2012/01/printing-with-support-extreme-overhangs/

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Flex Camera Case

description.text:
This case was designed to hold a Raspberry Pi Zero W and a Raspberry Pi camera v2. This is a perfect setup to run OctoPi 3D printer software and utilize the Pi camera for time-lapses. It could also be used as a web cam unit.

The mounting system was created to accommodate custom designed mounts for any application. The mounting holes are 19.5mm on center.

You'll need the following hardware:

  • (4) M3 x 10mm screws
  • (2) M3 x 6mm screws
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W (ideally)
  • Raspberry Pi Camera v2 *affiliate link
    or
  • Raspberry Pi NoiR Camera v2 *affiliate link
  • Lens kit from Amazon *affiliate link

https://youtu.be/vQyZMP_mq4M

Printer:

FolgerTech FT-5

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print the case halves on their respective faces. Print the mounts flat-side down. You may need to adjust print sizes (i.e. 0 - 2%) depending on your printer's extrusion precision. Print with no supports unless absolutely necessary.

Assembly

Follow the video for assembly instructions. It's pretty simple actually, but here are some general guidelines:

  • Do not over-tighten screws
  • Be sure your lens is mounted flat and not contacting the Pi Camera lens

You can design our own attachable mount to suit your needs. The mounting holes are 19.5mm on center, so as long as you follow that simple rule, you should be able to create any type of mount.

Replica of the Rocketeer Helmet from the Disney film.
I decided to revisit this model to make it smoother.
Needed something to hold my 14 USB memory sticks, so I created this for y'all.

I needed to sort out my USB pen problem, they are all scattered over my desk and hard to find because I have no room on my desk for any more things (yes, it's messy) so I wanted to put my USB pens on the side of my desk (I might move them to the wall above the desk because they are easily bumped and broke!) I couldn't find one big enough to hold every USB stick I own, whilst also being able to mount them to the wall. So I opened 123D Design and got to work. 9 Hours of work, designing, scaling and printing (mine took 4hrs,51min to print), it looks great! I am pretty happy with the outcome and I hope someone else gets use out of it too!

You can't carry tools in your carry on bags, so I made a wrench to loosen the top cap on an Aspire Triton 2 tank. Printing at 100% will be a tight fit, you may want to print at 101-102% depending on the accuracy of your machine and shrinkage of your material. I printed these originally in PETG at 100% and it worked for me, when printed in ABS I had to print at 102%.

title: Bucket Desiccant Standoff
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To keep my filament dry, I store it in 5 gallon buckets. I had been using small containers to hold desiccant, but it wasn't enough for the volume. I would have to cook it every couple weeks. So I needed to get more in there so I poured about 10mm into the bottom of the bucket. This is working great at keeping things dry, but, if I ever needed the spool at the bottom, I had to remove the embedded desiccant from it. I needed to raise that bottom spool off the desiccant so created this thing. It holds the bottom spool about 15mm above the bottom of the bucket and out of the desiccant and is 195mm in diameter.

I am using standard 5 gallon buckets you can get at home improvement stores. For the lid, I use a screw on lid (https://www.amazon.com/Gamma2-4123-Gamma-Seal-Lid/dp/B0089QJQTS/ref=pd_yo_rr_bia_t_1?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=772EGX9Y79P7NSW75B83) in which I have mounted a hygrometer/thermometer (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01E4WGCBA/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to know when it is time to recharge the desiccant.

comments.text: I can't believe I never considered using a bucket for this. Thank you.

print_settings.Notes:: No supports are required! I used a second color on the cover. If you wish to do so the cover thickness is .1" (2.54mm), and the letters are .4" (2mm) high. For a better result when printing the led tubes turn the heat down slightly since they are so small.

description.text:
DC Motor Controller Box
This is a box to house a DC motor controller to control speed and direction of a DC motor. The controller bolts on the bottom of the box with four M3 x 6mm long screws. The lid bolts onto the top of the box with eight M3 x 6mm long screws. I used heat-set brass thread inserts for the mounting threads. On the controller there is a yellow light for “on” and two red lights for “forward” and “reverse”. I designed tubes that transfer light from the leds thru cover lenses so that they are visible from the outside of the box. A rocker switch sets; forward, reverse, or off. And a potentiometer controls the motor speed. I used panel mount female DC panel mount barrel jack for the external power connections from the power supply and to the motor.

Assembly Instructions:
Once all the components are printed out use super glue to attach the led tubes to the cover plate. Then glue the lenses to the tubes. Next use a soldering iron to install the heat-set inserts into the empty holes in the housing, there are 12 holes in total. Take the knob and the nut off the potentiometer to install it into the cover. Disconnect the wires from the rocker switch and install it on the cover plate and then rewire the switch back to the controller. Solder wires onto the DC barrel jacks and then install the jacks in the housing. Install the controller in the housing using four M3 screws. Connect the wires from the DC barrel jacks to the controller. Be sure you connect the power correctly from the inlet jack to the controller because if these are wrong you will fry the controller. The outlet power phases to the motor don’t matter. Install the cover plate on the box and the controller is complete.

Required Components:

Motor Controller
PN: A16090700UX0248
Manufacture: Uxcell
Voltage: 10-30vdc/ 3amp
You can find it on Uxcells site or I got mine on amazon for $10:
http://www.uxcell.com/1030v-120w-pwm-motor-speed-regulator-controller-forward-reverse-switch-p-1020549.html

DC GearMotor (optional)
Any motor under 3amps will work but I used this one
PN: A16051100UX0484
Manufacture: Uxcell
Voltage: 24vdc/ 1amp
RPM: 200 (20-1000 available same gearmotor)
You can find it on Uxcells site or I got mine on amazon for $14:
http://www.uxcell.com/24v-200rpm-speed-6mm-shaft-dia-cylindrical-shape-geared-motor-tjp37rg249i-p-971392.html

Panel Mount DC Barrel Jack
Size: 2.1mm x 5.5mm
Panel Hole Size: 7.8mm
Qty: 3
I purchased mine from e-bay, they were like 10 for $1, but they also have them on amazon. Just make sure you get the two pin concentric style, the three pin style won’t fit.

Thread Inserts
M3x.5mm thread, 5.6mm od x 3.8mm lg. brass
QTY: 12
You can find the threaded inserts on Mcmaster:
https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a331/=16t62av

Power Supply
You will need a power supply. Any power supply from 10-30vdc will work just make sure it has a 5.5mm x 2.1mm barrel connector. I purchased a 24vdc x 3 amp power supply for $12 on Amazon.

Double Male Adapter Cable
You will need a cable with 2.1mm x 5.5 male plugs on both ends for connecting the controller to the motor cap housing. I found five of them on e-bay for $3.

Required hardware:

  1. M3 X .5 X SOCKET HEAD CAP SCREW 6M LG. – 4X
  2. M3 X .5 X BUTTON HEAD CAP SCREW 6M LG. – 8X

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5rFH3zaFnCk

No supports are required! I used a second color on the cover. If you wish to do so the cover thickness is .1" (2.54mm), and the letters are .4" (2mm) high. For a better result when printing the led tubes turn the heat down slightly since they are so small.
This is a customizable chain mail. You can select your number of rows and columns in the scad file.

Here are my take on some cosplay Wolverine claws (Logan style). I've been looking to create some Logan claws, just in case I decide to go as Old Man Logan this year, but could not find exactly what I was looking for. Other claws that I have found were either unfinished or too long for my printer. So I created my own claws: double bladed, come in 2 pieces with pins to align them when putting them together, and a simple handle. Depending on the size of your hands, you can scale them all up or down to fit you better.

There are 3 different claws: A, B, C. These go from pointer to pinky. Why 3? Well I didn't want any gaps between the claw and my knuckles, so I tweaked each claw to fit better. I have also angled the notches in the handle so that the blades will splay a bit. Looks cooler and easier to get your knuckles into the claw assembly.

As you can see in the picture, I covered the handle with black gaffers tape: one to hide it, and two to soak up some of the sweat from wearing them for a while. Let me know if you have any questions.
